block.p: Federal Reserve Cuts Rates To Revive Slowing Economy The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point for the second time this month, making clear that it intends to wage an aggressive battle against the growing possibility of a recession.

While offering some reassuring words about the economy's prospects over the long run, the Fed also signaled that it would probably cut rates further in coming months, saying that ''the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future.'' [Page A1.]

The stock market retreated after the rate cut. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.16 points, to 10,887.36. But the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 7.72 points, to 1,366.01. The Nasdaq composite index fell 65.62 points, or 2.3 percent, to 2,772.73. [C10.]

AOL Time Warner Reports a Loss The newly formed AOL Time Warner reported a fourth-quarter loss of $1.09 billion because of costs related to the merger. The loss translated into 25 cents a share, compared with a loss of $201 million, or 5 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue grew 8 percent, to $10.2 billion. Shares of AOL Time Warner fell 3.2 percent, or $1.75, to $52.56. [C4.]
CNNfn will get a new name, CNN Money, a slightly new focus, wider distribution and more cooperation from its corporate siblings, AOL Time Warner executives said. [C4.]

Anthem Plans to Be Publicly Held Anthem, which operates Blue Cross health plans, is expected to announce that it is moving toward a reorganization that would permit it to become a publicly traded company. [C7.]

Enron to Halt Some Power Service A division of Enron that sells power directly to large industrial and commercial customers in California has decided to halt the service to dozens of its customers because of the potential for mounting losses. [A16.]
Senate Democrats and Republicans clashed over whether the Bush administration had done enough to help California extricate itself from an electricity crisis. [A16.]

A New Campaign for Lane Bryant Lane Bryant, the specialty retailer for plus-size women, has decided to take a different advertising tack and feature its first male celebrity. It is using Mr. Big, a character in the hit HBO series ''Sex and the City'' portrayed by the actor Chris Noth, who is shown enjoying the company of several beautiful plus-size models. Advertising. [C8.]

Coke Net Up, but Sales Are Sluggish Capping off a trying year marred by layoffs, lawsuits and a tougher consumer market for sodas, Coca-Cola announced a sharp rebound in fourth-quarter earnings, but its sluggish sales raised questions about whether it has enough momentum to accomplish the full turnaround it has pledged for 2001. [C7.]

Philip Morris Profit Falls Short Philip Morris said that its profit rose 8.3 percent in the fourth quarter as its tobacco business grew faster than the overall industry in the United States and key overseas markets and as new products bolstered its food profits. But the results were slightly below Wall Street expectations for the quarter. [C2.]
A Super Bowl Economics Lesson The price of tickets to the Super Bowl offers a lesson in the economics of supply and demand. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. [C2.]
